question.text: Which of the following statements is not correct about rusting of iron?

options.text: Coating of iron surface by tin prevents rusting, even if the tin coating is peeling off.

When <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>pH</mi></math> lies above <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>9</mn></math> or <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>10</mn></math> , rusting of iron does not take place.

Dissolved acidic oxides <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><msub><mi>SO</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mo>,</mo><msub><mi>NO</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></math> in water act as catalyst in the process of rusting.
Rusting of iron is envisaged as setting up of electrochemical cell on the surface of iron object.

solution.text:
Rusting refers to the creation of rust on the surface of iron objects or structures, which is a mixture of iron oxides. In a water-rich environment, rust is created through a redox interaction between oxygen and iron (or high levels of moisture). The creation of a layer of a red, flaky substance that quickly crumbles into a powder characterises the rusting of iron.

As the tin coating is peeled off, then iron is exposed to the atmosphere.

Because rusting occurs as a result of a chemical interaction between iron and air in the presence of moisture, it is a chemical alteration. The iron would not have rusted and gained a brown texture from its dull grey one if the chemical interaction between them had not occurred. As a result, a new substance known as rust forms on the surface of iron.

Hence, the answer is A.
